{{Use British English|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Joseph Watson, 1st Lord Manton, by John Lavery (1856-1941).jpg|thumb|200px|Joseph Watson, 1st Baron Manton, by [[John Lavery]], 1922]] [[File:JosephWatsonBaronManton.jpg|thumb|200px|Joseph Watson, 1st Baron Manton. Portrait sketch by John A M Hay, 1923]] '''Joseph Watson, 1st Baron Manton''' (10 February 1873 – 13 March 1922) was an English industrialist from [[Leeds]], Yorkshire.
He was chairman of Joseph Watson & Sons Ltd, soap manufacturers, of [[Leeds]] and a [[board of directors|director]] of the [[London and North-Western Railway]], in the late 19th century the largest [[joint stock company]] in the world. He became in later life a pioneer of industrialised agriculture in England and a successful racehorse owner.<ref name=Venn>{{acad|id= WT890J|name=Watson, Joseph}}</ref> He was step-great-grandfather to [[David Cameron]], former [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]].<ref>His 2nd son Hon. Robert Fraser Watson (1900–1975) married in 1961 (as his 2nd wife) Enid Levita (d.1995),(Debrett's Peerage, 1968, p.739, Baron Manton; p.577, Mount baronets) formerly wife of Ewen Donald Cameron, grandfather of David Cameron</ref>
==Early life== Watson was the only son of George Watson, soap manufacturer, of Donisthorpe House near [[Moor Allerton]], Leeds, [[Yorkshire]]. He was educated at [[Repton School]] and [[Clare College, Cambridge]].<ref name=Venn /> he was recalled to the family firm before completing his degree, becoming chairman at a young age.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}
==Soap business== [[File:Matchlesscleanser.jpg|thumb|200px|Advertisement for Watsons ''Matchless Cleanser'' soap, advertised by the company in 1910 as "the most popular soap in Great Britain".<ref>[http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Joseph_Watson_and_Sons] 1910 advertisement showing a hand counting 6 points in favour of the product, 3rd point of 6</ref> Illustration by Howard Davie, August 1898. Other brands of Joseph Watson & Co Ltd were: ''Sparkla'' polishing soap, ''Nubolic'' disinfectant soap, ''Venus'' toilet soap and ''Bumpo'' soap powder<ref>http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Joseph_Watson_and_Sons</ref>]]
===Joseph Watson & Sons=== Joseph went to work at his grandfather's company, Joseph Watson & Sons,{{#tag:ref|The limited company Joseph Watson & Sons had been founded by Joseph his grandfather and had grown out of a hide tanning business established by James Watson in 1816<ref>Horsforth Cragg Hill and Woodside Conservation Area Appraisal and Management Plan, 8 August 2011, p.6 [http://www.leeds.gov.uk/docs/horsforth%20cragg%20hill%20and%20woodside%20caa%20%28august%202011%29.pdf#page=3&zoom=page-actual,205,0]</ref> at Woodside, [[Horsforth]], {{convert|5|mi|km}} NW of central Leeds. The business was an adjacent diversification<ref>Charles Wilson. (1954). ''The History of Unilever.'' London: Cassell. '''1'''. p. 13</ref> from the small family farm, which covered the area between today's Outwood Lane and Broadway, with further rented ground to the SE.<ref>1838 Tithe Map, Woodside, (search for Horsforth, Guiseley) with list of owners & tenants of each parcel of ground, see especially central holding of Jonas Watson, plot 861 "tan yards, buildings", a triangular site one of the sides of which is formed by today's "Tanhouse Hill Lane" [http://tithemaps.leeds.gov.uk Tithe Map 1838.]</ref> Additional rented land to the SE, comprising a handful of pastures, was on the Headingley estate of the Earl of Cardigan.<ref>1838 Tithe Map, Woodside [http://tithemaps.leeds.gov.uk Tithe Map 1838]</ref> The family also owned a paper mill at Woodside, and is believed to have built numerous stone houses for their workers in Paradise Place and Watson Row in Regent Road<ref>Horsforth Cragg Hill and Woodside Conservation Area Appraisal and Management Plan, 8 August 2011, p.6</ref> The former existence of the original business is today memorialised by the name of ''Tanhouse Hill'' Lane, to the east of which it stood, within a triangular site.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}|group="nb"}} and turned the company from the medium-sized concern built up by his father and uncle Charles into one which ruled the soap market of North-East England, with national and international markets, becoming [[William Lever, 1st Viscount Leverhulme|William Lever]]'s biggest rival<ref>Charles Wilson. (1954). ''The History of Unilever.'' London: Cassell. '''1'''. pp. 13, 123.</ref>{{#tag:ref|Watson was amongst the first of the established manufacturers to follow Lever's heavy advertising and revolutionary marketing techniques,{{#tag:ref|Lever started as a grocer who bought in soap from several suppliers, including Watson's, and branded them "Sunlight". Lever soon set up his own manufacturing plants, but by then Watson's had founded its own brands and independent marketing abilities. |group=lower-alpha}} offering prizes such as day trips to Brighton and visits to Paris to view the Grecian sculpture Venus de Milo, in exchange for soap wrapper returns. In 1885 production had been 100 tons per week, which rose fivefold by 1906. One of the by-products was [[glycerine]], sold for the manufacture of explosives. The company, known locally as "Soapy Joe's" was based after 1861 at the Whitehall Road Soapworks, Leeds, strategically placed between the River Aire, from which [[palm oil]] shipped in from around the world was unloaded, and the former railway terminal, from which the finished product was dispatched. It became one of the largest employers in the city, producing brands such as "Matchless Cleanser", "Venus" and "Nubolic".{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}|group="nb"|name=""}}
===Soap Trust monopoly=== [[File:Soaptrust.jpg|thumb|300px|Cartoon from The ''Daily Mirror'', 22 October 1906. A parody of William Lever, whose factory was named "[[Port Sunlight]]".]] On 4 August 1906 Watson and William Lever, by then the largest manufacturer, met in the [[St. Pancras Renaissance London Hotel|Grand Hotel]] in London to finalise a plan to set up a "Soap Trust" which would merge the major soap manufacturers into a monopoly, thereby gaining economies of scale in advertising and production costs. Watson favoured the use of a parent company whilst Lever preferred a scheme of exchange of shares between participating companies to bind them together. This occurred during a period of many corporate trusts in the United States.{{#tag:ref|The scheme was in imitation of hundreds of similar trusts which had been established in the USA following [[John D. Rockefeller]]'s pioneering organisation of the [[Standard Oil]] Co. in 1882 as a virtual monopoly combination of many small independent oil companies. The manufacturers in their idealism foresaw benefits from trusts to both consumer and producer from economies of scale, yet abuses occurred. A sugar trust evaded $4M of customs duty, and the creation of a beef trust seemed a threat to cheap food supplies. The dangers to the consumer were soon understood by the politicians and the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]] of 1890 was the response. The Act was not totally successful and [[Theodore Roosevelt]] in his second presidency launched a new "trust-busting" policy at about the same time the British soap trust was being established.|group="nb"}} The scheme was strongly opposed by the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' newspaper which campaigned for a boycott by its readers of the trust brands. Profits at participating firms were thereby severely reduced. The Northcliffe Press in its expanding and highly popular campaign overstepped the mark by falsely asserting trust soaps to be made from scented fish oil. Although Watson and Lever won substantial libel damages from the press, losses in reputation and profits had been suffered all round. On the proposal of Watson and Crosfield, another large manufacturer, the scheme was abandoned in November 1906. By then Watson had already disposed of much of his shareholding, previously all held by himself and his uncle Charles, to William Lever, in exchange for [[Lever Brothers]] shares to set up the trust.<ref>Charles Wilson. (1954). ''The History of Unilever.'' London: Cassell. '''1'''. Chapter 6, The Crisis of 1906, pp. 72–88.</ref>
===Lever Brothers and Jurgens=== [[File:SoapyJoesShaft.jpg|thumb|200px|"Soapy Joe's Shaft", Whitehall Rd. Leeds. A surviving ventilation shaft of the former Leeds Electricity Dept., which sub-station stood adjacent on the north to Whitehall Soap Works]] In 1912/13 Watson sold much of his remaining shareholding to Lever ([[Lever Brothers]] Ltd., later [[Unilever]]) and sold to him the remainder in July 1917, but remained as chairman. He had sold his half share in the Planter's Margarine Co Ltd. to Lever in July 1915, a joint venture established in November 1914 at Godley in Cheshire with Levers, in response to Government anxiety at the wartime loss of Dutch supplies, which by 1915 was the country's second largest margarine manufacturer.<ref>Wilson, I, pp.227–9</ref> He had supplied it from his Olympia Oil & Cake Co. Ltd. at Selby, Yorks which operated the largest linseed oil crushing and refining plant in Europe. It also hardened whale oil and in 1917 during WWI was allocated by the government 21% (later 25%) of British whale oil for hardening.<ref>Wilson, I, p.239; Lever's had 47% and Crosfield's 32%</ref> Watson then suffered substantial losses in an unsuccessful speculation in linseed and he sold Olympia Oil & Cake to the Dutch firm [[Antonius Johannes Jurgens|Jurgens]], which had outbid Levers.<ref>Wilson, I, p.249</ref>
==Pioneer of industrialised agriculture== Spurred on by wartime food shortages, Watson began the pioneering of industrialised agriculture, and he funded the Agricultural Research Department at [[Leamington Spa]]. He founded the Olympia Agricultural Co Ltd. and invested much of his proceeds into agricultural estates totalling some {{convert|20000|acre|km2}} at Selby (Yorks), the 5,500 acre Manton Down Estate (Wiltshire), Sudbourne (Suffolk), [[Offchurch]] (Warwickshire)<ref>W.G. Rimmer. (1961). "Men Who Made Leeds." ''Leeds Journal.'' 32: pp. 143–6.</ref> and at Thorney (Cambridgeshire).<ref>McKie</ref> His Olympia Oil & Cake Co. under the brand name "OCO" produced animal feeds for dairy cows, calves, lambs and pigs,<ref>http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Olympia_Oil_and_Cake_Co#cite_note-2</ref> all from the new source of linseed oil. The company acquired sites near Selby within the parish of [[Barlby]] between 1909–10 and their buildings later dominated the road and river frontages.<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=23002 Victoria County History (VCH), County of York East Riding, Volume 3: Ouse and Derwent wapentake, and part of Harthill wapentake (1976), pp. 47–52 Hemingbrough: Barlby]</ref> Soon after 1910 the company built the first "village estate" of workers' housing in the area which was later expanded by other nearby employers. Before 1921 the "Olympia Hotel" opened near the site at Barlby Bank, which took its name from the company and used a sign showing seed-crushing machinery.<ref>VCH</ref> The company since 1952 became part of British Oil and Cake Mills Ltd.
Following Manton's death his executors claimed he had put £1,000,000 into agriculture and received £750,000 from sales of the properties.
==Wartime munitions work== [[File:WatsonLloydGeorgeTelegram.jpg|thumb|300px|Telegram of 21 June 1916 from Lloyd George to Watson. [[Amatol]] is an explosive consisting of TNT and Ammonium Nitrate.]] At the start of the [[First World War]] Watson's industrial and organisational expertise was used to assist the government in the establishment and operation of national munitions factories, most notably at the First National Shell Filling Factory at [[Barnbow]], Leeds.<ref name=Cox /><ref name=Jackson />
Following the heavy consumption of munitions in the opening battles of WWI at the Somme, the ''Northcliffe Press'' (''[[Daily Mail]]'') brought to the public's attention what became known as "[[Shell Crisis of 1915|The Shell Crisis]]", signifying that the nation had given little thought to securing long-term munitions supplies needed to successfully wage an unprecedented protracted war. The [[H. H. Asquith|Asquith]] government fell, to be replaced by that of [[David Lloyd George|Lloyd George]], recently appointed Minister of Munitions to resolve the crisis. Watson as chairman of a six-man "Leeds Munitions Committee" made up from local industrialists, formed in August 1915, was charged by the government to immediately establish the first of 12 National Shell Filling Factories. A factory was promptly established on a {{convert|400|acre|km2|adj=on}} greenfield site at Barnbow, close to Leeds. It resembled a small town of detached houses and huts more than a traditional factory, to contain and localise any accidental explosions. It remained the largest such operation in the country, having despatched 566,000 tons of finished ammunition overseas by the Armistice. At its height it employed 16,000 workers, 93% of whom were women and girls.{{#tag:ref|Two members of the directing board were on duty at Barnbow every day, and the board met at least once a month to receive reports. The factory was largely self-contained for reasons of national security, operating under great secrecy. It operated its own farm including dairy and slaughterhouse. Kitchens and accounting department were equipped with the latest electric machinery. Nursing facilities and dentists were provided.|group="nb"}} Its fire brigade responded to three accidental explosions, the most serious of which occurred in 1916, killing 35 women and injuring many more.<ref name=Cox>Tony Cox. "Barnbow Munitions Factory 1915–18." ''The Barwicker No. 47.'' Barwick-in-Elmet Historical Society.</ref><ref name=Jackson>Eric Jackson. (2007). [http://www.pontefractus.co.uk/history/barnbow-lasses.htm ''The Barnbow Lasses.''] [http://www.pontefractus.co.uk Pontefractus Local History].</ref>{{#tag:ref|Due to wartime censorship, no public account of the accidents was made. The memorials to these unfortunate victims are almost the only trace which remains of the operation on the site today.<ref name=Cox /><ref name=Jackson />|group="nb"}}
==Racehorse owner== [[File:Love in Idleness.jpg|thumb|200px|''Love-in-Idleness'', Watson's winner of the 1921 [[Epsom Oaks|Oaks]]]] [[File:JosephWatson&Lemonora GrandPrixDeParis Winner 1921.jpg|thumb|200px|Watson with his colt ''Lemonora'' after winning the [[Grand Prix de Paris]] at [[Longchamp Racecourse|Longchamp]] on 26 June 1921. For moving images see [http://www.britishpathe.com/video/french-grand-prix-1/query/PARIS+GRAND+PRIX+ British Pathe] ]] Watson hunted with the Bramham Moor Foxhounds in Yorkshire, near his home at Linton Spring, Wetherby. He was a prominent [[racehorse]] owner and in 1918 acquired from [[Alec Taylor, Jr.]] the famous [[Manton, Wiltshire|Manton]] training establishment near [[Marlborough, Wiltshire|Marlborough]] in Wiltshire.<ref>[http://www.brianmeehan.co.uk/manton/history ''History of Manton''.] Brian Meehan at Manton. Retrieved 7 July 2013.</ref> and spent £30,000 on yearlings.<ref name="trove.nla.gov.au">Argus Newspaper, Melbourne, Australia, 15 March 1922 "Death on Hunting Field"[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4685808]</ref> In 1921 he won [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] with [[Love in Idleness]], and the [[Grand Prix de Paris]], the world's richest racing prize (400,000 Francs), with ''Lemonora'' which also had gained third place in the Derby that year, all ridden by jockey [[Joe Childs]]. He was termed by the racing press Mr "Lucky" Watson.<ref>For movie footage of Lemonora winning the Grand Prix and Watson with his horse in the winner's enclosure, see [http://www.britishpathe.com/video/french-grand-prix-1/query/PARIS+GRAND+PRIX+ British Pathe]; [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rJgjMF5FBSs you tube] Item title reads: "World's Richest Racing Prize. "Lemonora" wins Grand Prix for Mr "Lucky" Watson. Paris, France. We see people milling about and a lot more sat in the stands. L/S of the horse race, we see them coming round the bend and racing up the track. M/S of the jockey on "Lemonora" after the race, M/S of Mr Watson who takes his top hat off to the camera, he holds the horses reins"</ref>
==Philanthropy== [[File:JosephWatsonBustLeeds.jpg|thumb|200px|Monument to Joseph Watson in Leeds General Infirmary.]] In 1921 Watson donated £50,000 to the Leeds General Infirmary, of which he was a board member from 1906 to his death. The monies were used to replace some of its investments which had to be sold during WWI.<ref>''British Medical Journal.'' 2 July 1921, p. 24</ref>{{full citation needed|1=Article name, author|date=July 2013}} A half-length bronze bas-relief portrait of Watson in his baronial robes is displayed there in the George Street entrance hall, under which is inscribed ''A Wise Counsellor and Generous Benefactor.''
==Elevation to the peerage == [[Image:Compton-verney.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Compton Verney, Warwickshire.]] On 25 January 1922 he was raised to the peerage for his war services<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=32563 |date=30 December 1921 |page=10709 |supp=y}}</ref> as '''Baron Manton''' of [[Compton Verney]] in the County of Warwick.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=32598 |date=3 February 1922 |page=954}}</ref> He had purchased the Robert Adam neo-classical mansion [[Compton Verney House|Compton Verney]] and its {{convert|5079|acre|km2|adj=on}} estate in 1921 from Lord Willoughby de Broke, intending to make his seat there, which intention was not realised due to his sudden death in March 1922, before having taken up residence.{{#tag:ref|Conveyance 30 November 1921 DR 951/6/1 Warks. Archives.|group="nb"}} Whether his elevation, at the behest of Lloyd-George, was the result of a political donation, has not been proved but the title is not amongst those generally quoted by commentators as falling into this category.<ref name="De-la-Noy">Michael De-la-Noy. ''The Honours System.'' London 1985. pp. 100–118.</ref>{{#tag:ref|The title was created in the New Year's Honours List, not the "notorious" Birthday Honours List of June.<ref name="De-la-Noy" />|group="nb"}}
==Armorials== [[File:JosephWatson&SonsLtd Leeds TradeMark1906.PNG|thumb|200px|1906 Ram's head trademark of Joseph Watson & Sons Ltd. Detail from design on one of 500 promotional sewing machines given as prizes by the company in 1906. Collection of Abbey House Museum, Leeds]] [[File:Watson (Baron Manton) Arms.png|thumb|200px|Arms of Baron Manton: ''Argent, on a chevron azure between 4 martlets 3 in-chief and 1 in-base sable a crescent between 2 roses of the field'']] Joseph Watson adopted, or was allocated by the heralds,{{#tag:ref|Seemingly the practice for most 20th-century Watson baronets also{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}|group="nb"}} a variation of the armorials of the Watson Earls of Rockingham, which earldom had become extinct in 1746 on the death of [[Thomas Watson, 3rd Earl of Rockingham]]. The arms of Baron Manton became :"Argent, on a chevron azure between 4 martlets 3 in-chief and 1 in-base sable a crescent between 2 roses of the field". For supporters he also adopted a variant of Rockingham: "On either side a gryphon per fesse azure and argent, charged on the shoulder with a rose also argent".<ref name="Debrett's Peerage">P. W. Montague-Smith (editor). (1968). ''Debrett's Peerage, Baronetage, Knightage and Companionage.'' Kelly's Directories. p. 739 "Manton"</ref> The arms of the Earls of Rockingham were: "Argent, on a chevron azure between 3 martlets sable as many crescents or". The Rockingham supporters were: "2 griffins argent ducally gorged or".<ref name="Burke's Amorials">Sir Bernard Burke. (1884). ''The general armory of England, Scotland, Ireland, and Wales; comprising a registry of armorial bearings from the earliest to the present time .'' London: Harrison and Sons. p. 1083.</ref> Manton adopted the Rockingham motto without alteration: "Mea Gloria Fides" (Trust is my Renown). For his crest, Manton adopted a variant of the oak tree arms of the 17th-century Watson family of Saughton, Edinburgh: crest of Baron Manton: "a gryphon passant sable in front of an oak tree proper".<ref name="Debrett's Peerage" /> The armourials of Watson of Saughton were: "Argent, an oak tree growing out of a mount in base proper surmounted of a fess azure". The latter family was granted in 1818 the griffin supporters of the Earls of Rockingham, noted above.<ref name="Burke's Amorials" />{{#tag:ref|There is no evidence of any genealogical link between the family of Joseph Watson and either of the two families from which he adopted his armorials. Burke' Armorials, 1884 does however list 4 Watson families in Yorkshire all bearing variants of the Rockingham arms, therefore possibly lineal descendants. The heir of the 3rd and last Earl of Rockingham in the more ancient title of Baron Rockingham was [[Thomas Watson-Wentworth, 1st Marquess of Rockingham]], who built the palatial mansion [[Wentworth Woodhouse]] near Rotherham, Yorkshire. This house would come to have a connection with the [[Rupert Watson, 3rd Baron Manton|3rd Baron Manton]], whose maternal aunt Joyce Langdale of [[Houghton Hall, Yorkshire|Houghton Hall]], Sancton York, resided there following her 1956 marriage to the [[Earl Fitzwilliam|10th Earl FitzWilliam]], which family was heir to the Rockinghams.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1438732/Lord-Manton.html Daily Telegraph Obituary of 3rd Baron Manton]; Debrett's Peerage, 1968, p.453: seat of Earl Fitzwilliam in 1968: Wentworth Woodhouse, Rotheram</ref>}}
==Marriage and progeny== [[File:LadyMantonBySirJohnLavery.jpg|thumb|200px|Lady Manton, née Claire Nickols, wife of Joseph Watson, 1st Baron Manton, 1922 portrait by [[John Lavery]] matching portrait by same artist of Lord Manton]] In 1898 Joseph Watson married (Frances) Claire Nickols (d.1944), 3rd daughter of Harold Nickols (1848–1925), of Sandford House, Kirkstall, Leeds,<ref>Debrett's Peerage, 1968, p.740</ref> proprietor of "Joppa Tannery", 87 Kirkstall Road, Leeds. Joppa Tannery was built in 1828 by Harold's father Richard Nickols as an expansion from the small tannery he had established in Bramley in 1823. The Joppa Tannery employed 300–400 people at its height and produced "upper leather" for shoes. It closed briefly but was re-openrd by Harold Nickols in 1900 under the name "Harold Nickols Ltd". It continued to be run by Harold's son Richard III Nickols, and closed in 1955.<ref>[http://www.leodis.net/Display.aspx?resourceIdentifier=2314 Leodis – A Photographic Archive of Leeds]</ref> Watson had four sons by Claire Nickols:<ref>Debrett's Peerage, 1968, p.739</ref>
*[[Miles Watson, 2nd Baron Manton|(George) Miles Watson, 2nd Baron Manton]] (1899–1968), who after a brief military career, with his younger brother Robert continued his father's race-horse breeding programme, as a director of "Newmarket Bloodstock Ltd." *Robert Fraser Watson (1900–1975), ("Bobbie") with his eldest brother a director of "Newmarket Bloodstock Ltd." Destined for the army<ref>Obituary, ''The Racehorse'' magazine</ref> he attended [[Wellington College, Berkshire|Wellington College]] and [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst|Sandhurst]] and [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], where he was [[Master of Foxhounds|Master]] of the Cambridge University Draghounds. His military career was cut short by [[tuberculosis]] and to recuperate he moved to [[British Kenya|Kenya Colony]], where he became a member of the [[Happy Valley set]]. In March 1927 he became engaged to [[Beryl Markham|Beryl Clutterbuck]] (later [[Beryl Markham]]), the Colony's "Golden Girl",<ref>Lovell. Engagement announced in East African Standard newspaper, 19 March 1927, text see Lovell</ref> a racehorse trainer and later a pioneer aviator who became the first woman to fly across the Atlantic from east to west. The engagement was cancelled only 5 months later when she became engaged instead to [[Mansfield Markham]], which change "produced a great deal of amused speculation within the (Kenya) Colony, whose chief occupation and innocent delight was social gossip". Markham did not long retain her affections as in 1929 she commenced a very public affair with [[Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester]], son of King [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]]. "A generally held opinion was that Watson had a lucky escape".<ref>Lovell, Mary S., ''Straight on till Morning, the Life of Beryl Markham''[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=u3um6-uFF6EC&pg=PT107&lpg=PT107&dq=robert+fraser+watson&source=bl&ots=IIIG-JwuP_&sig=2nRGmkUqiFKHu2p8Zvy_jnK9pj0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik14vq-tPKAhWCyhoKHRaCAKEQ6AEILDAC#v=onepage&q=robert%20fraser%20watson&f=false]</ref> Watson himself had an interest in flying and in 1935 acquired an [[Avro 643 Cadet|Avro 643 Cadet Mk.II]] bi-plane, sold in 1937 to the [[List of aircraft of the Spanish Republican Air Force|Spanish Republican Air Force]].<ref>"Serial: G-ADEX (c/n.R820) This aircraft was owned by Capt. Hon Robert Fraser Watson/London SW3 (based Heston). In September 1937 it was sold to Spanish Republicans. Source: http://www.zi.ku.dk/personal/drnash/model/spain/[http://wp.scn.ru/en/ww15/o/1779/9_p/0]; http://www.airhistory.org.uk/gy/reg_G-A6.html</ref> Watson later served as deputy-chairman of the ''Hospitals for the Diseases of the Chest'',<ref name="Kelly 1969">Kelly's Handbook to the Titled, Landed and Official Classes 1969, London, 95th Edition, 1969, p.2041</ref> today the [[Royal Brompton Hospital]] in London.<ref>In 1948 Brompton Hospital came under the control of the NHS, and merged with the London Chest Hospital to become the Hospitals for the Diseases of the Chest [https://thefightagainsttuberculosis.wordpress.com/2015/03/10/the-hospital-for-consumption-and-diseases-of-the-chest-brompton/]</ref> His racehorse [[Dick Turpin (racehorse)|Dick Turpin]] won the 1933 [[Chester Cup]], ridden by [[Gordon Richards]]. In 1943 he sold his Dorset estate including Peggs Farm, Vale Farm and Manor Farm in the parishes of [[Sutton Waldron]] and [[Iwerne Minster]] to [[William Aitken, 1st Baron Beaverbrook|Lord Beaverbrook]].<ref>University of Nottingham, Manuscripts and Special Collections: "Ne 6 D 6/1/5/9: Copy conveyance from R.F. Watson to Lord Beaverbrook of Peggs Farm, Vale Farm and Manor Farm in the parishes of Sutton Waldron and Iwerne Minster, dated 20 Oct. 1943"[http://mss-cat.nottingham.ac.uk/Dserve/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqCmd=Show.tcl&dsqDb=Catalog&dsqSearch=%28PersonCode==NA42360%29&dsqPos=13]</ref> In December 1948 at Newmarket he sold his 7-year-old brood mare Ferry Pool for 18,000 guineas, a record price in England.<ref>http://www.sporthorse-data.com/d?showpic=10143711&nm=2&time=1444372335 Sold to the Sezincote Stud at Moreton-in-Marsh. The previous record had been 17,000 guineas achieved in 1942 for Olein and in 1925 for Straitlace</ref> He was step-grandfather to [[David Cameron]], former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, having married in 1961 (as his 2nd wife) Enid Levita (d.1995) (a [[lineal descendant]] of [[William IV of the United Kingdom|King William IV]] by his mistress [[Dorothea Jordan]]<ref>{{cite web |last=Lundy |first=Darryl |url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p10085.htm#i100850 |title= William IV Hanover, King of the United Kingdom |publisher=The Peerage |accessdate=9 July 2013}}{{Unreliable source?|failed=y |date=February 2013}}<!--Lundy is not a reliable source so cite Lundy's reliable source See [[WP:SAYWHEREYOUREADIT]]--> ThePeerage.com</ref>) formerly wife of Ewen Donald Cameron, and grandmother of David Cameron.<ref>Debrett's Peerage, 1968, p.739, Baron Manton</ref> *Alastair Joseph Watson (1901–1955), whose share of his paternal inheritance included the remnant of the Sudbourne Estate in Suffolk, 7,650 acres of which were advertised for sale as "the late Lord Manton's Suffolk estate" in the Times newspaper of 31 March 1922, in order to pay death duties.<ref>As reported in the New York Times, 7 May 1922, p.1: "Bargains in Castles"..."That taxation is causing English landlords to dispose of their realty holdings for whatever they will bring is shown by the fact that the total area of the landed properties comprised in a full-page announcement in The Times of London, England, by a single firm exceeds 79,000 acres"[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/05/07/issue.html]</ref> The 1,200 acre<ref>http://www.zoopla.co.uk/property-history/3/chillesford-lodge/sudbourne/woodbridge/ip12-2an/36658752</ref> [[Chillesford|Chillesford Lodge]] Estate, the estate's Victorian "model farm" built in 1875 by [[Sir Richard Wallace, 1st Baronet]]<ref>[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-506341-chillesford-lodge-model-farm-chillesford#.ViaMgCtjQqc Listed building text]</ref> of Sudbourne Hall, the noted art collector and illegitimate son of the 4th [[Marquess of Hertford]], where the [[Red Poll]] breed of cattle had been developed in the 19th century,<ref>Historic Landscape Appraisal Sudbourne Park, 2010{{cite web|url=http://apps3.suffolkcoastal.gov.uk/planningonlinedocuments/115888_8.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208073856/http://apps3.suffolkcoastal.gov.uk/planningonlinedocuments/115888_8.pdf |archivedate= 8 December 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.essentialsuffolk.com/property-chillesford-model-farm/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208151856/http://www.essentialsuffolk.com/property-chillesford-model-farm/ |archivedate=8 December 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> is retained in 2015 by his descendants. The famous "Sudbourne" prefixed herds of Red Poll cattle and the famous "Sudbourne" stud<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=RwpA5PNNXBcC&pg=PT18&lpg=PT18&dq=sudbourne+suffolk+punch&source=bl&ots=bNKRrP-aar&sig=Ra-lEf_6krlSp_OSgaFA90VkNOw&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=sudbourne%20suffolk%20punch&f=false Evans, George Ewart, ''Horse Power and Magic'']</ref> of [[Suffolk Punch]]<ref>e.g. "Sudbourne Premier", a stallion bred by Lord Manton in 1919 won a number of prizes between 1921 and 1924 [https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O312757/suffolk-punch-statuette-suffolk-punch-haseltine-herbert/]</ref> heavy horses, were retained by Watson and won several prizes. In 1936 he built the Chillesford Polo Ground, a private club open to family and friends where teams played by invitation only. It represented "country polo at its best" and used an advanced system of irrigation sprinklers, then unique in England, imported by Watson from the USA where he had seen them in use at the [[Santa Barbara Polo Club]] in California. Spectators were encouraged and were admitted free of charge, with printed programmes with colour covers provided, a further innovation for a small polo club at the time. The club closed during [[World War II]] but re-opened in 1948.<ref>Laffaye, Horace A., ''Polo in Britain: A History'', London, 2012, p.126 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=EsxYBYIFEoYC&pg=PA126&lpg=PA126&dq=sudbourne+watson&source=bl&ots=apeNqAueZE&sig=3OCGCJRWKDWu-q2i-wVu7BeGflg&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=sudbourne%20watson&f=false]</ref><ref>Springfield, Maurice, ''Hunting Opium and Other Scents'', Halesworth, Suffolk, 1966, Chapter 8, "Searching for Game"{{cite web|url=http://www.earnshaw.com/shanghai-ed-india/tales/library/opium/opium.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304100548/http://www.earnshaw.com/shanghai-ed-india/tales/library/opium/opium.htm |archivedate= 4 March 2016 |df= }}: "Later came glorious Sundays as guest of the late Alastair Watson on his perfect ground at Chillesford, near Orford, in a gorgeous setting among pine trees. Before 1940 the ponies on which he mounted his guests were thoroughbred, or near thoroughbred. After the war, until his untimely death, all mounts were selected Arabs flown to England in specially chartered planes. Those were certainly the golden days of polo in East Anglia."</ref> He is said to have been trampled to death by ponies during a polo match, after which the polo ground was ploughed up.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Fmc8t8VfdLgC&pg=PA70&lpg=PA70&dq=Chillesford+Polo&source=bl&ots=0sdRVawpH8&sig=xsJ0iN_uZV2YiqDTlbv5AdPhaw8&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Chillesford%20Polo&f=false Mitchell, Laurence, ''Suffolk Coast and Heaths Walks'', p.70]</ref> *(Richard) Mark Watson (1906–1979), a diplomat who served as attaché at the British Embassy in Washington DC (1930–2) and in Paris (1932–4).<ref name="Kelly 1969"/> In 1965 he was decorated with the [[Iceland]]ic [[Order of the Falcon]].<ref>http://www.thepeerage.com/p31563.htm</ref> Unmarried.
==Death and burial== He died in March 1922, aged only 49, from a heart-attack, whilst out hunting beside two of his sons.<ref name="trove.nla.gov.au"/> They were with the Warwickshire Foxhounds, at Upper Quinton, close to his new mansion. He died having held his title for less than two months. He was buried at his nearby manor of Offchurch, in his hunting apparel. His estate was sworn for probate at exactly one million pounds. His widow continued to reside until her death in 1936 in the mansion house of [[Offchurch Bury]]. A portrait of Joseph Watson mounted on a hunter was painted by Lynwood Palmer.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}
==Notes== {{Reflist|group="nb"}} {{Reflist|group=lower-alpha}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * David J. Jeremy (editor). (1984). ''Dictionary of Business Biography''. Butterworths. '''5''': part 2. pp. 690–2. * Charles Kidd, David Williamson (editors). (1990).''Debrett's Peerage and Baronetage''. New York: St Martin's Press. {{Page needed |date=February 2013}} * "Obituary: Joseph Watson," ''[[The Times]]'', 14 March 1922. *{{Rayment|date=February 2012}} * McKie, David, ''Soap Opera or Suds Law?'', The Guardian newspaper, 15 April 2004 [https://www.theguardian.com/Columnists/Column/0,5673,1192258,00.html]
==External links== *{{Hansard-contribs | mr-joseph-watson-1- | Lord Manton}} * [http://www.leodis.net/display.aspx?resourceIdentifier=2011215_171830&DISPLAY=FULL Leodis: A photographic archive of Leeds – photo of Joseph Watson & Sons Ltd Whitehall Road factory circa 1918] *[http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Joseph_Watson_and_Sons Grace's Guide: British industrial history – Joseph Watson & Sons Ltd.] *[http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Olympia_Oil_and_Cake_Co#cite_note-2 Grace's Guide: British industrial history – Olympia Oil & Cake Co.] * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1438732/Lord-Manton.html Daily Telegraph Obituary of 3rd Baron Manton] * [http://www.comptonverney.org.uk/ Compton Verney House website]

revision.text:
[[File:Villa Shatterhand-2.jpg|thumb|Villa Shatterhand]] The '''Karl May Museum''' is a museum in [[Radebeul]], Germany named after the German author [[Karl May]], containing artifacts from May's life as well as from life on the [[American frontier]] and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] life of that era.
==Museum history== German author [[Karl May]] (1842–1912), wrote many books about the [[American frontier]] and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] featuring the fictional characters [[Winnetou]] (a Mescalero-Apache Chief) and [[Old Shatterhand]] (a white European settler). Mays' books were popular in Germany and created a mystique about the "Wild West" in German popular culture.<ref name=NYT/>
The museum opened in 1928 in [[Radebeul]], in the house where May had lived, called Villa Shatterhand.<ref name=NY/> It was founded during a peak of interest in the US frontier and native Americans, fostered in part by the [[Sarrasani]] circus, which was headquartered in nearby [[Dresden]], and which was very popular in the 1920s.<ref name=Weaver>{{cite book|last1=Weaver|first1=Jace|title=Other Words: American Indian Literature, Law, and Culture|date=2001|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=9780806133522|language=en|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gQj_aQhYvfEC}}</ref>{{rp|84}} Sarassani and Native American members of the circus came to the opening, and the Native Americans performed death songs for May.<ref name=Weaver/>{{rp|84}}
The museum was founded by May's widow and an eccentric Austrian named [[:de:Patty Frank|Ernst Tobis]], who was a fan of May's work and had travelled to the American frontier, and liked to tell [[tall tales]] about his time there.<ref name=NYT/> Tobis donated a large collection of artifacts to help found the museum's collection, which included 17 [[Scalping|scalps]], some of them from Native Americans.<ref name=NYT/><ref name=Knight2/>
When the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]] took over Germany, they appropriated the museum and the image of May, and were especially focused on swastikas that appeared in some of the Native American artwork. Hitler Youth were encouraged to visit the museum and to hear stories from Tobis.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Penny|first1=H. Glenn|title=Kindred by Choice: Germans and American Indians Since 1800|date=2013|publisher=UNC Press Books|isbn=9781469607641|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HV4DAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA166&lpg=PA166|language=en|page=166}}</ref>
After World War II, the original museum was in [[East Germany]] and a replica was built in [[Bamburg]] in [[West Germany]].<ref name=Weaver/>{{rp|73}} A person who called himself [[Chief Buffalo Child Long Lance]] became associated with the museum shortly after the war ended.<ref name=Weaver/>{{rp|84}}
From 1956 to 1984, the museum in Radebul was called the "Indianer Museum", because May's books were suppressed by the East German government, in part because of the association with the Nazis, but also because the books were viewed as leading people to want to travel, which the government did not allow.<ref name=NY>{{cite news|last1=Galchen|first1=Rivka|title=Wild West Germany|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/04/09/wild-west-germany|work=The New Yorker|date=2 April 2012|language=en}}</ref> During the [[Cold War]] placards in the museum in Radebeul and its displays were refactored to describe oppression of Native Americans by the US, as part of Soviet [[propaganda]] efforts to rally indigenous people against the West.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tóth|first1=György Ferenc|title=From Wounded Knee to Checkpoint Charlie: The Alliance for Sovereignty between American Indians and Central Europeans in the Late Cold War|date=2016|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=9781438461236|pages=128ff|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fGwJDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA128|language=en}}</ref> Some East Germans also did work with the [[American Indian Movement]].<ref name=NY/> [[File:Karl May Museum Skalp.jpg|thumbnail|upright=0.5|Scalp exhibited at the museum]] The museum in Radebul was given its original name again in 1986, as the East German government moved to reclaim May. The renaming led to an exhibition focused on May in February, which had 4,000 visitors a day, and people waited for three hours outside to get in.<ref name=NY/> After the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, attendance at the Radebul museum dropped from around 300,000 people per year to around 60,000, as people could travel to the US instead of visiting the museum, which had been one of the only sources of information about Native Americans in East Germany.<ref name=NY/>
In 2010, according to the ''South China Morning Post'', US activists began seeking [[repatriation]] of the scalps.<ref name=SCMP>{{cite news |url= http://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/1446600/karl-may-museum-under-fire-over-display-native-american-scalps | work= South China Morning Post | title= Karl May Museum under fire over display of Native American scalps |date= 11 March 2014 | accessdate= 3 May 2018 |quote= For four years, United States activists have been calling for the return of the scalps. The display of scalps has been banned in the US since 1990.}}</ref> Berlin-based journalist Mark Worth brought the scalps to the attention of Karen Little Coyote of the [[Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes]], who wrote a letter asking for the scalps to be returned in the fall of 2013.<ref name=WildWest>{{cite news |author= Knight, Ben |url= http://www.dw.de/wild-west-museum-in-row-over-native-american-scalps/a-17498259 |title= Wild West museum in row over Native American scalps | date = 10 March 2014 |work=Deutsche Welle |accessdate=3 May 2018}}</ref> In 2013, the German Museums Association issued a guideline on the care of human remains, listing scalps from peoples who "fashioned trophies from the heads of their killed enemies" as an exception to "human remains acquired in a context of injustice".<ref name=NYT/> In March 2014, Cecil E. Pavlat, who works on return of artifacts for the [[Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Chippewa Indians]], wrote a letter asking for return of the scalps.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news |author=Eddy, Melissa | url= https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/18/world/europe/germanys-fascination-with-american-old-west-native-american-scalps-human-remains.html |work= New York Times |title= Germany's fascination with American old West, Native American scalps human remains |date= 17 August 2014 |accessdate= 3 May 2018}}</ref><ref name=Oltermann>{{cite news |author= Oltermann, Philip |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/10/german-museum-karl-may-native-american-scalps |title= German museum in row with US activists over tribal scalps |work= The Guardian |date= 10 March 2014 |accessdate= 3 May 2018}}</ref> Later in 2014, the Museum agreed to turn the scalps over to another institution for authentication.<ref name=ICT>{{cite news |author=Haircrow, Red |date= 14 June 2014 |url= https://indiancountrymedianetwork.com/news/indigenous-peoples/an-agreement-is-reached-regarding-scalps-at-the-karl-may-museum/ |work= Indian Country Today |title= An agreement is reached regarding scalps at the Karl May Museum |accessdate= 3 May 2018}}</ref> The Museum had not returned the scalps as of 2016, saying there were doubts about the original story of the provenance of the 17 scalps,<ref name=Knight2>{{cite news |author= Knight, Ben|url= http://www.dw.com/en/karl-may-museum-hangs-on-to-native-american-scalp/a-19020100 |title= Karl May Museum hangs on to Native American scalp |work= Deutsche Welle |date = 2 February 2016 |accessdate= 3 May 2018}}</ref> although they did remove them from public display.<ref name=Muse>{{cite journal |url= https://muse.jhu.edu/article/628637/summary |title= Revisiting Winnetou: The Karl May Museum, Cultural Appropriation, and Indigenous Self-Representation |author= King, Lisa Michelle |work= Project Muse}}</ref>
The director of the museum in Radebul from 1985 to 2014 was René Wagner; Christian Wacker was appointed director in 2018.<ref name=NY/><ref>{{cite news|title=Radebeul: Christian Wacker wird Direktor im Karl-May-Museum|url=https://www.mdr.de/kultur/karl-may-museum-radebeul-christian-wacker-100.html|work=Mitteldeutsche Rundfunk|date=January 11, 2018|language=de-DE}}</ref>
The museum received a donation of new artifacts in 2018.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schirmer|first1=Nina|title=Wertvolle Raritäten fürs Karl-May-Museum|url=http://www.sz-online.de/nachrichten/wertvolle-raritaeten-fuers-karl-may-museum-3868589.html|work=SZ-Online|date=27 January 2018|language=de-DE}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.karl-may-museum.de Karl May Museum official site]
{{coord missing|Saxony}}
[[Category:Radebeul]] [[Category:Human trophy collecting]] [[Category:Museums in Saxony]] [[Category:Karl May]]

revision.comment: Rescued 4 archive links; reformat 4 links. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
The following is a list of '''members of the [[International Rehabilitation Council for Torture Victims]]'''.
==Members of the IRCT<ref>''[http://www.irct.org/about-us/the-members/find-irct-members.aspx Retrieved from IRCT website], 12 September 2012</ref>==
'''[[Albania]]''' * [http://www.arct.org/ Albanian Rehabilitation Centre for Trauma and Torture Victims] (ARCT)
'''Argentina''' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120615091206/http://www.eatip.org.ar/ Equipo Argentino de Trabajo e Investigación Psicosocial] (EATIP)
'''Armenia''' * Foundation against Violation of Law (FAVL)
'''Australia''' * [http://www.asetts.org.au Association for Services to Torture and Trauma Survivors] (ASeTTS) * [http://www.companionhouse.org.au Companion House Assisting Survivors of Torture and Trauma] * [http://www.melaleuca.org.au Melaleuca Refugee Centre, Torture and Trauma Survivor Service NT] * [http://www.mrchobart.org.au Phoenix Centre - Support Service for Survivors of Torture and Trauma] * [http://www.qpastt.org.au Queensland Program of Assistance to Survivors of Torture and Trauma] (QPASTT) * [http://www.startts.org Service for the Treatment and Rehabilitation of Torture and Trauma Survivors] (STARTTS) * [http://www.sttars.org.au%20 Survivors of Torture and Trauma Assistance and Rehabilitation Service Inc.] (STTARS) * [http://www.foundationhouse.org.au%20 The Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture Inc. - Foundation House] (VFST)
'''Austria''' * [http://www.hemayat.org Organisation for Support of Survivors of Torture and War] (HEMAYAT) * [http://www.zebra.or.at Intercultural Centre for Counselling and Psychotherapy] (ZEBRA) * [http://www.omega-graz.at Society for Victims of Organised Violence and Human Rights Violations] (OMEGA Health Centre)
'''Bangladesh''' * Centre for Rehabilitation of Torture Survivors (CRTS)
'''Bolivia''' * [http://www.itei.org.bo Instituto de Terapia e Investigación sobre las secuelas de la tortura y la violencia estatal] (ITEI)
'''Bosnia and Herzegovina''' * [http://www.ctvbih.com Association for Rehabilitation of Torture Victims - Centre for Torture Victims, Sarajevo] (CTV) * [http://www.vivezene.ba%20 Vive Žene Centre for Therapy and Rehabilitation] (CTR)
'''Brazil''' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20001204160200/http://www.torturanuncamais-rj.org.br/ Grupo Tortura Nunca Mais/Rio de Janeiro] (GTNM/RJ)
'''Bulgaria''' * [http://www.acet-bg.org%20 Assistance Centre for Torture Survivors] (ACET)
'''Cambodia''' * [http://www.tpocambodia.org%20 Transcultural Psychosocial Organization Cambodia] (TPO Cambodia)
'''Cameroon''' * Trauma Centre Cameroon (TCC)
'''Canada''' * [http://www.ccvt.org%20 Canadian Centre for Victims of Torture] (CCVT) * [http://www.emcn.ab.ca%20 Program for Survivors of Torture and Trauma at the Edmonton Mennonite Centre for Newcomers] (ECSTT) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131225172930/http://www.web.ca/~rivo/ Intervention Network for Persons having been subjected to Organised Violence] (RIVO) * [http://www.vast-vancouver.ca Vancouver Association for Survivors of Torture] (VAST)
'''Chile''' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121007002056/http://www.cintras.org/ Centro de Salud Mental y Derechos Humanos] (CINTRAS)
'''Colombia''' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070527163742/http://www.corporacionavre.org/ Corporación AVRE - Apoyo a Víctimas de violencia sociopolítica pro Recuperación Emocional] (AVRE) * Centre for Psychosocial Assistance (CAPS-CO)
'''Congo (Democratic Republic of the)''' * Centre Psycho Médical pour la Réhabilitation des Victimes de la Torture (SOPROP/CPMRVT) * OASIS Centre for Treatment and Rehabilitation of Victims of Torture and Trauma (OASIS DRC) * [http://www.savecongo.populus.org%20 SAVE Congo DR] * The Centre Mater Misericordiae (CMM-CD)
'''Croatia''' * [http://www.irctzg.org%20 International Rehabilitation Centre for Torture Victims - Zagreb] (IRCT Zagreb)
'''Denmark''' * [http://www.oasis-rehab.dk%20 OASIS Treatment and Counselling for Refugees] * [http://www.rct.dk%20 Rehabilitation and Research Centre for Torture Victims] (RCT) * [http://www.rct-jylland.dk%20 Rehabilitation Centre for Torture Victims - Jutland] (RCT-Jutland)
'''Ecuador''' * Fundación para la Rehabilitación Integral de Víctimas Violencia (PRIVA)
'''Egypt''' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120902142059/https://alnadeem.org/en/node/23 El Nadeem Center for Psychological Management and Rehabilitation of Victims of Violence]
'''Ethiopia''' * Rehabilitation Center for Victims of Torture in Ethiopia (RCVTE)
'''Finland''' * [http://www.hdl.fi%20 Centre for Torture Survivors in Finland] (CTSF)
'''France''' * [http://www.parcours.asso.fr%20%20 Parcours d'Exil]
'''Georgia''' * [http://www.empathy.ge%20 EMPATHY, Psycho-Rehabilitation Centre for Victims of Torture, Violence and Pronounced Stress Impact] (RCT/Georgia - EMPATHY) * [http://www.gcrt.ge%20 Georgian Center for Psychosocial and Medical Rehabilitation of Torture Victims] (GCRT)
'''Germany''' * [http://www.bzfo.de Berlin Center for the Treatment of Torture Victims] (bzfo) * [http://www.exilio.de%20 Exilio Hilfe für Flüchtlinge und Folterüberlebende e.V.] * [http://www.mfh-bochum.de%20 Medical Care Service for Refugees Bochum] (MFH-Bochum)
'''Greece''' * Medical Rehabilitation Centre for Torture Victims (MRCT)

page.title: List of foodborne illness outbreaks by death toll

revision.text:
This is a '''list of [[foodborne illness]] outbreaks by death toll''', caused by [[infectious disease]], [[heavy metals]], [[chemical hazards|chemical contamination]], or from natural toxins, such as those found in [[poisonous mushrooms]].
==List by agent== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year !!Event !!Agent!! Food!! Company !! Infected !! Deaths !! Notes |- |2017–current. |[[2017–18 South African listeriosis outbreak]] |[[Listeria]] |[[Processed meat]] |[[South Africa]] |{{sort|01000|1,000}} |{{sort|00180|180}} |A widespread ongoing [[Listeria monocytogenes]] outbreak from contaminated Deli meats from [[Enterprise Foods]] a subsidiary of [[Tiger Brands]]. It is the worlds worst listeria outbreak. |- |2016 |[[Campylobacteriosis]] from unchlorinated drinking water |''[[Campylobacter]]'' |[[Drinking water]] |[[Hastings, New Zealand|Hastings]] District Council |{{sort|05500|5,500}}<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dia.govt.nz/diawebsite.nsf/Files/Report-Havelock-North-Water-Inquiry-Stage-2/$file/Report-Havelock-North-Water-Inquiry-Stage-2.pdf|title=Report of the Havelock North Drinking Water Inquiry: Stage 2|last=Government Inquiry into Havelock North Drinking Water|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> |{{sort|00004|4}}<ref name=":02" /> |Drinking water in New Zealand is normally required to be disinfected with either [[chlorine]], [[chlorine dioxide]], [[ozone]] or [[UV light]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.health.govt.nz/system/files/documents/publications/drinking-water-standards-2008-jun14.pdf|title=Drinking-water Standards for New Zealand 2005 (Revised 2008)|last=New Zealand Ministry of Health|first=|date=|website=New Zealand Ministry of Health|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> However, 'secure bore water' is exempt from this requirement.<ref name=":1" /> The source of bacteria was identified by [[genotyping]] as coming from sheep faeces.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.dia.govt.nz/vwluResources/Report-Havelock-North-Water-Inquiry-Stage-1/$file/Report-Havelock-North-Water-Inquiry-Stage-1.pdf|title=Report of the Havelock North Drinking Water Inquiry: Stage 1|last=Government Inquiry into Havelock North Drinking Water|first=|date=May 2017|website=www.dia.govt.nz|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-27}}</ref> Once sheep faeces entered a stream near the water bores, the drinking water supply had no residual disinfectant to kill the contaminating bacteria. 5,500 people became ill out of a population of 14,000; 45 people were hospitalised;<ref name=":0" /> and four people died.<ref name=":02" /> The town's water supply is now chlorinated, and chlorination will continue for the foreseeable future.<ref name=":02" /> |- |2011 |[[2011 Germany E. coli O104:H4 outbreak|2011 Germany ''E. coli'' O104:H4 outbreak]] |[[E. coli O104:H4|''E. coli'' O104:H4]] |[[fenugreek]] [[sprouting|sprouts]]<ref name=poster>{{cite news |author=[[William Neuman (reporter)|William Neuman]] |coauthors= |title=The Poster Plant of Health Food Can Pack Disease Risks |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/11/business/11sprouts.html?scp=2&sq=Germany%20E.%20coli%2045%20sprouts&st=cse |quote=German authorities said on Friday that they had conclusively identified sprouts as the cause of the E. coli infections that have swept Europe since early May, ... |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=June 10, 2011 |accessdate=2011-10-08 }}</ref> | |{{sort|03950|>3,950}}<ref>{{cite news |author=[[European Food Safety Authority]] |coauthors= |title=E.coli: Rapid response in a crisis |url=http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/press/news/120711 |quote= Across the EU more than 3,100 cases of bloody diarrhoea and more than 850 of haemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), a serious condition that can lead to kidney failure, were reported... |newspaper= |date=July 11, 2012 |accessdate=2012-10-02 }}</ref> |{{sort|00053|53}}<ref>{{cite news |author=[[European Food Safety Authority]] |coauthors= |title=E.coli: Rapid response in a crisis |url=http://www.efsa.europa.eu/en/press/news/120711 |quote= there were 53 confirmed deaths. |newspaper= |date=July 11, 2012 |accessdate=2012-10-02 }}</ref> ||Deadliest bacterial foodborne outbreak in Europe. Deadliest ''E. coli'' outbreak. |- |1985 || [[1985 California listeriosis outbreak in cheese]]|| [[Listeria]] || [[queso fresco]] || Jalisco Cheese||{{sort|00086|>86}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00000562.htm |title=Epidemiologic Notes and Reports Listeriosis Outbreak Associated with Mexican-Style Cheese -- California|date=June 21, 1985 |accessdate=2011-10-08 |quote=Between January 1, and June 14, 1985, 86 cases of Listeria monocytogenes infection were identified in Los Angeles and Orange Counties, California. Fifty-eight of the cases were among mother-infant pairs. Twenty-nine deaths have occurred: eight neonatal deaths, 13 stillbirths, and eight non-neonatal deaths. An increased occurrence of listeriosis was first noted at the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center; all cases were in pregnant Hispanics, and all appeared to be community-acquired. A systematic review of laboratory records at hospitals in Los Angeles and Orange County identified additional cases throughout the area. |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] }}</ref> ||{{sort|00050|47 or 52}}<ref name=cantaloupe/> ||Deadliest bacterial foodborne outbreak in US.<ref name=cantaloupe>{{cite news |author=[[William Neuman (reporter)|William Neuman]] |coauthors= |title=Deaths From Cantaloupe Listeria Rise |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/28/business/deaths-from-cantaloupe-listeria-rises.html?src=me&ref=general |quote=At least 13 people in eight states have died after eating cantaloupe contaminated with listeria, in the deadliest outbreak of food-borne illness in the United States in more than a decade, public health officials said on Tuesday. ... The outbreak appeared to be the third worst in the United States attributed to any form of food-borne illness, in terms of the number of deaths, since the C.D.C. began regularly tracking such outbreaks in the early 1970s. The deadliest outbreak in the United States since then occurred in 1985, when a wave of listeria illness, linked to Mexican-style fresh cheese, swept through California. A federal database says 52 deaths were attributed to the outbreak, but news reports at the time put the number as high as 84. The second-deadliest outbreak was in 1998 and 1999, when there were at least 14 deaths and four miscarriages or stillbirths in a listeria outbreak linked to hot dogs and delicatessen meats. Some sources put the death toll in that outbreak as high as 21. ...|newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=September 27, 2011 |accessdate=2011-09-29 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1370/is_n6_v22/ai_6589512 |work=FDA Consumer |title=Invisible villains; tiny microbes are biggest food hazard |first=Marian |last=Segal |quote=Summer 1985: In Southern California, the largest number of food poisoning deaths recorded in recent U.S. history is traced to Mexican-style soft chesse. Of the 142 reported cases, there were 47 deaths, including 19 stillbirths and 10 infant deaths. The killer -- Listeria monocytogenes. |year=1988 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802235700/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1370/is_n6_v22/ai_6589512/ |archivedate=2009-08-02 |df= }}</ref>. |- |2011 || [[2011 United States listeriosis outbreak in cantaloupes]] ||Listeria ||[[cantaloupe]]<ref name=cantaloupe/> || Jensen Farms || {{sort|00146|146}} ||{{sort|00030|30}}<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Multistate Outbreak of Listeriosis Linked to Whole Cantaloupes from Jensen Farms, Colorado (Final update) |url=https://www.cdc.gov/listeria/outbreaks/cantaloupes-jensen-farms/120811/index.html |quote=A total of 146 persons infected with any of the four outbreak-associated strains of Listeria monocytogenes were reported to CDC from 28 states. The number of infected persons identified in each state was as follows: Alabama (1), Arkansas (1), California (4), Colorado (40), Idaho (2), Illinois (4), Indiana (3), Iowa (1), Kansas (11), Louisiana (2), Maryland (1), Missouri (7), Montana (1), Nebraska (6), Nevada (1), New Mexico (15), New York (2), North Dakota (2), Oklahoma (12), Oregon (1), Pennsylvania (1), South Dakota (1), Texas (18), Utah (1), Virginia (1), West Virginia (1), Wisconsin (2), and Wyoming (4). (...) Thirty deaths were reported: Colorado (8), Indiana (1), Kansas (3), Louisiana (2), Maryland (1), Missouri (3), Nebraska (1), New Mexico (5), New York (2), Oklahoma (1), Texas (2), and Wyoming (1). Among persons who died, ages ranged from 48 to 96 years, with a median age of 82.5 years. In addition, one woman pregnant at the time of illness had a miscarriage. |date=8 December 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2012}}</ref> ||Second deadliest bacterial foodborne outbreak in US. Second deadliest Listeria outbreak. |-1996 1996 Wishaw E. coli outbreak E. coli O157 meat local butcher >200 20 At the time the world's deadliest outbreak of E. coli poisoning. Butchers John M. Barr & Son provided cooked meat products to several events including a birthday party and a pensioners' luncheon club. The source of the contamination was traced to a boiler used for cooking joints and stew, and a vacuum packing machine used for cooked and raw meats.[23] | 2008 || [[2008 Canada listeriosis outbreak]] || [[Listeria]] || [[cold cuts]] || [[Maple Leaf Foods]]<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Canada Expands Recall of Cold Cuts and Raises Death Toll |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/26/business/worldbusiness/26food.html?scp=2&sq=Maple%20Leaf%20Foods%20listeriosis&st=cse |quote=Over the weekend, Maple Leaf expanded its recall, which began with two types of cold cuts, to include 220 products from the factory, which is one of 24 operated by the company. Separately on Monday, Lucerne Foods, which is based in Calgary, announced a recall of prepared sandwiches it made using Maple Leaf meats for supermarkets and convenience stores in Western Canada. |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=August 25, 2008 |accessdate=2011-10-08 }}</ref>|| {{sort|00050|>50}} ||{{sort|00022|22}}<ref> {{cite news|url=http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/alert-alerte/listeria/listeria_2008-eng.php |title=Listeria monocytogenes outbreak |publisher=[[Canadian Food Inspection Agency]] |quote=The Public Health Agency of Canada has updated its case numbers from last year's national listeriosis outbreak. ... |date=2009-03-12 |accessdate=2009-03-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207083151/http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/alert-alerte/listeria/listeria_2008-eng.php |archivedate=2009-02-07 |df= }}</ref>|| Deadliest foodborne outbreak in Canada. |- |1996 |1996 Wishaw E. coli outbreak |[[Escherichia coli O157:H7|E. coli O157]] |[[meat]] |local butcher |{{sort|00200|>200}} |{{sort|00020|20}} |At the time the world's deadliest outbreak of E. coli poisoning. Butchers John M. Barr & Son provided cooked meat products to several events including a birthday party and a pensioners' luncheon club. The source of the contamination was traced to a boiler used for cooking joints and stew, and a vacuum packing machine used for cooked and raw meats. |- |1998 || [[1998 United States listeriosis outbreak]] ||Listeria || [[cold cuts]] and [[hot dogs]]||Bil Mar Foods||{{sort|00100|>100}} || {{sort|00018|18 or 21}}<ref name=cantaloupe/><ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Listeria Fear Forces Recall of Hot Dogs |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/26/us/listeria-fear-forces-recall-of-hot-dogs.html |quote=... The move comes as the company tries to polish a wholesome image tarnished by the nationwide recall in December 1998 of about 15 million pounds of hot dogs and luncheon meat after listeria was spotted. The meat was linked 21 deaths and more than 100 illnesses in 22 states. |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=March 26, 2000 |accessdate=2011-09-30 }}</ref>|| |- |2014 || [[2013–2014 Danish listeriosis outbreak]] ||[[Listeria]] ||Spiced lamb roll, pork, sausages, bacon, liver pâté etc.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title= Listeria Impacted Products| quote=List of listeria impacted products and distributors| publisher = Danish Veterinary and Food Administration|date=August 2014 | url=http://www.foedevarestyrelsen.dk/SiteCollectionDocuments/25_PDF_word_filer%20til%20download/Webalerts/LISTERIA%20200814%20kl%2016.30.pdf }}</ref> || Jørn A. Rullepølser || {{sort|00037|> 37}} ||{{sort|00015|15}}<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Outbreak of Listeriosis Linked to meat from Jørn A. Rullepølser A/S, Denmark |url=http://www.ssi.dk/Aktuelt/Temaer/Sygdomsudbrud/Listeriaudbrud.aspx |quote=A total of 15 deaths with strains of Listeria monocytogenes were reported by The Danish Ministry of Health. The outbreak has been linked to spiced lamb roll, pork, bacon, sausages, liver pâté and other meat products. |date=8 September 2014 |accessdate=8 September 2014}}</ref> ||Deadliest{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} foodborne outbreak in Denmark. |- | 1985 ||[[1985 United States salmonellosis outbreak in milk]] || [[Salmonella]]|| [[milk]] ||Hillfarm Dairy|| {{sort|05295|5,295}}<ref name=margolis>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Salmonella Outbreak is Traced |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/04/17/garden/salmonella-outbreak-is-traced.html |quote=About 6,644 cases of samonella poisoning have been reported and 5,295 have been confirmed in five states, most of them in Illinois, according to Jeremy Margolis, the acting Illinois public health director. At least nine deaths have been linked to the outbreak. The other states affected by the outbreak are Indiana, Iowa, Michigan and Wisconsin. |newspaper=[[United Press International]] in the [[New York Times]] |date=April 17, 1985 |accessdate=2011-09-29 }}</ref>|| {{sort|00009|9}}<ref name=margolis/> ||Largest foodborne salmonella outbreak in milk. |- | 2008 || [[Peanut Corporation of America|2008 United States salmonellosis outbreak in peanuts]]||[[Salmonella]] ||[[peanut]]s||[[Peanut Corporation of America]]||{{sort|00200|>200}} || {{sort|00009|9}}||Largest foodborne salmonella outbreak in peanut butter. One of the largest food recalls in United States history.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Peanut Company Sent Products Before Test Results |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/12/health/policy/12peanut.html |quote=It has also led to one of the largest food recalls in the nation's history ... |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=February 11, 2009 |accessdate=2011-11-09 }}</ref> |- | 2002 ||[[2002 United States listeriosis outbreak in poultry]]|| [[Listeria]]|| [[poultry]] ||[[Pilgrim's Pride]]|| {{sort|00050|>50}}<ref name=usnwr/> || {{sort|00008|8}}<ref name=usnwr/> || |- | 2015–present<ref name="ecdc–efsa-2018">{{cite web |url=https://ecdc.europa.eu/sites/portal/files/documents/22-02-2018-RRA-Listeria-Finland.pdf |title=Multi-country outbreak of Listeria monocy togenes serogroup IVb, multi-locus sequence type 6, infections probably linked to frozen corn |date=24 March 2018 |website=ecdc.europa.eu |publisher=[[European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control]] |access-date=22 March 2018}}</ref> || [[European listeriosis outbreak (2015–present)]] || ''[[Listeria monocytogenes]]''{{r|ecdc–efsa-2018}} || [[Frozen food|Frozen]] [[corn]] suspected{{r|ecdc–efsa-2018}} || Hungarian supplier → Hungarian processing company → Polish storage service → Polish packer{{r|ecdc–efsa-2018}} || {{sort|00032|32}}{{r|ecdc–efsa-2018}} || {{sort|00006|6}}{{r|ecdc–efsa-2018}} || {{As of|2018|03|08|post=,}} the ongoing outbreak has affected five European Union countries: * Austria: 2 confirmed cases (1 fatal) * Denmark: 4 confirmed cases (1 fatal) * Finland: 14 confirmed cases (2 fatal) * Sweden: 6 confirmed cases (2 fatal) * United Kingdom: 6 confirmed cases (no fatalities) {{r|ecdc–efsa-2018}} |- |1994 |''[[Salmonella]]'' in [[ice cream]] |''[[Salmonella]]'' |[[ice cream]] |[[Schwan's|Schwan's Sales Enterprises]] |{{sort|224000|224,000}} |{{sort|00000|0}} |An estimated that 224,000 people across the United States suffered from ''Salmonella enteritidis'' gastroenteritis after eating Schwan’s ice cream when raw, unpasteurized eggs were hauled in a tanker truck that later carried pasteurized ice cream to the Schwan's plant, and the ice cream premix wasn't pasteurized after delivery to the plant.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hennessy|first=Thomas W.|last2=Hedberg|first2=Craig W.|last3=Slutsker|first3=Laurence|last4=White|first4=Karen E.|last5=Besser-Wiek|first5=John M.|last6=Moen|first6=Michael E.|last7=Feldman|first7=John|last8=Coleman|first8=William W.|last9=Edmonson|first9=Larry M.|date=1996-05-16|title=A National Outbreak ofSalmonella enteritidisInfections from Ice name=penn/>|| {{sort|00003|3}}<ref name=penn>{{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwR/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5247a5.htm |title=Hepatitis A Outbreak Associated with Green Onions at a Restaurant – Monaca, Pennsylvania, 2003 |accessdate=2011-10-08 |date=November 28, 2003|quote=The Pennsylvania Department of Health and CDC are investigating an outbreak of hepatitis A outbreak among patrons of a restaurant (Restaurant A) in Monaca, Pennsylvania. As of November 20, approximately 555 persons with hepatitis A have been identified, including at least 13 Restaurant A food service workers and 75 residents of six other states who dined at Restaurant A. Three persons have died. Preliminary sequence analysis of a 340 nucleotide region of viral RNA obtained from three patrons who had hepatitis A indicated that all three virus sequences were identical. Preliminary analysis of a case-control study implicated green onions as the source of the outbreak. ... |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] }}</ref>||Largest foodborne hepatitis outbreak. |- |2006 || [[2006 North American E. coli O157:H7 outbreak in spinach|2006 North American ''E. coli'' O157:H7 outbreak in spinach]] ||[[E. coli O157:H7|''E. coli'' O157:H7]] || [[spinach]] || [[Dole Foods]]<ref name=usnwr>{{cite news |author=[[Jennifer O'Shea]] |coauthors= |title=Timeline: Deaths and Illnesses Caused by Food Contamination |url=http://health.usnews.com/usnews/health/articles/070520/28food.timeline.htm |quote=Prewashed, bagged spinach from Dole was contaminated with ''E. coli''. At least 205 consumers fell ill; three died. Investigators traced the strain back to the field in California and said that in this instance, washing could not have removed the bacteria. |newspaper=[[U.S.News & World Report]] |date=May 20, 2007 |accessdate=2011-10-10 }}</ref>|| {{sort|00205|>205}}<ref name=usnwr/> ||{{sort|00003|3}}||<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Libby Sander]] |title=Source of Deadly E. Coli Is Found |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/13/us/13spinach.html?scp=6&sq=E.%20coli%20spinach&st=cse |quote=Cattle manure collected from a California ranch under investigation by federal and state authorities contains the same strain of ''E. coli'' that killed three people and sickened nearly 200 in a recent outbreak linked to tainted spinach, federal and state food safety officials said Thursday. ... |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date= October 13, 2006 |accessdate=2011-10-10 }}</ref> |- | 1963 || [[1963 botulism case from canned tuna]] || [[Botulism]]|| [[canned tuna]] || [[A&P]] || || {{sort|00002|2}}||<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Deaths Spur Tuna Hunt In Detroit Area |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VJBOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MwEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7129,4239012&dq=death+botulism&hl=en |quote=Dr. Robert Solomon, who treated the second victim, said he and a pathologist attributed her death to "botulism" and that "everything points to type the ... |newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]] |date=March 20, 1963 |accessdate=2011-10-10 }}</ref> |- |1922 || [[1922 Loch Maree botulism outbreak]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Horowitz|first=B Zane|date=2011|title=The ripe olive scare and Hotel Loch Maree tragedy|url=https://doi.org/10.3109/15563650.2011.571694|journal=Clinical Toxicology|volume=49|pages=345-347|doi=10.3109/15563650.2011.571694|issn=1556-3650|}}</ref> ||[[Botulism]] || Duck paste || Lazenby's ||{{sort|00008|8}}||{{sort|00008|8}}||Six guests and two staff members at the Loch Maree Hotel in Scotland were fatally poisoned by sandwiches made with Botulinus-contaminated duck paste. This was the first incident in the UK in which botulism was conclusively identified as the cause and remains the only large incident of microbial food contamination in the UK with 100% reported fatalities. |- | 1971 || [[1971 botulism case from Bon Vivant soup]] || [[Botulism]]||[[vichyssoise soup]]|| Bon Vivant Company|| {{sort|00002|2}}<ref name=vivant/>|| {{sort|00001|1}}<ref name=vivant>{{cite news|first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=An Examination of FDA's Recall Authority |url=http://leda.law.harvard.edu/leda/data/729/Curatolo05.html |quote=The incident did not take a toll only on the company, however. Bon Vivant did not have adequate records and controls of production lots and distribution in order to trace the products quickly. The company also did not have the finances or manpower necessary to run a successful recall program. As a result, the FDA had to seize all the Bon Vivant soup throughout the country, more than a million cans in all. FDA said the seizure occupied 125 man years of FDA time, enough for 2,000 ordinary factory inspections for preventive purposes. After some squabbling in the courts, where the owner of the company sought to recover the seized cans for resale under the company's new name, "Moore & Co.," the soup was eventually incinerated, at the cost of nearly $150,000 to the federal government. As for Moore & Co., it appears the resurrection of the company was short-lived. |publisher=[[Harvard Law School]] |date= |accessdate=2007-09-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016235604/http://leda.law.harvard.edu/leda/data/729/Curatolo05.html |archivedate=2007-10-16 |df= }}</ref> || |- |1996 || [[1996 Odwalla E. coli outbreak|1996 Odwalla ''E. coli'' outbreak]] || [[E. coli O157:H7|''E. coli'' O157:H7]] || unpasteurized [[apple juice]] || [[Odwalla]] || {{sort|00066|66}}<ref name=fb>{{cite news |url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=FB&p_theme=fb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAE8AA7075DF9F7&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title= Odwalla Agrees to Pay $1.5M Fine|accessdate= 2008-08-08|date= July 24, 1998|quote= Representatives of juice maker Odwalla Inc. agreed in a Fresno courtroom Thursday to pay a record $1.5 million criminal penalty for the 1996 ''E. coli'' outbreak that killed a Colorado girl and sickened at least 66 other people. The Half Moon Bay company admitted to 16 misdemeanor charges as part of a plea agreement stemming from the outbreak traced to contaminated apple juice made at the firm's plant in Dinuba. |publisher= [[The Fresno Bee]]}}</ref>||{{sort|00001|1}}<ref name=deadly>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/04/us/deadly-bacteria-a-new-threat-to-fruit-and-produce-in-us.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|title= Deadly Bacteria a New Threat To Fruit and Produce in U.S.|accessdate= 2008-08-11|author= [[Christopher Drew (reporter)|Christopher Drew]] and [[Pam Belluck]]|date= January 4, 1988|publisher= [[New York Times]]|quote=Interviews with former Odwalla managers and company documents show that in the weeks before the outbreak, Odwalla began relaxing its standards on accepting blemished fruit and reining in the authority of its own safety officials, culminating in tense, dramatic moments on the morning of Oct. 7, 1996, the day the contaminated juice was pressed. ...}}</ref> ||Unpasteurized juice sold for the health market. Rotten apples used when safety officer was overruled.<ref name=deadly/> |- |2005 || [[2005 South Wales E. coli O157 outbreak|2005 South Wales ''E. coli'' O157 outbreak]] ||[[E. coli O157|''E. coli'' O157]] ||meat|| local butcher|| {{sort|00157|157}}<ref name=wrong/> ||{{sort|00001|1}}<ref name=wrong>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=E.coli butcher jailed for a year. A butcher has been jailed for a year for food safety offences which led to a fatal E.coli outbreak in 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/south_east/6983113.stm |quote=Mr Walters said one vacuum-packing machine was "wrongly used" for both raw and cooked meats. "It was not uncommon for juices from raw meat to get into the vacpacker. "There was blood on the trays and workers were having to wipe it off while they were packing cooked meat. "One employee said he was told by Tudor not to use the vacpacker for cooked meat whenever food inspectors were visiting." |newspaper=[[BBC]] |date= 7 September 2007 |accessdate=2011-10-07 }}</ref> || Largest ''E. coli'' outbreak in Wales.<ref name=wrong/> Second largest ''E. coli'' outbreak in UK.<ref name=wrong/> |- |}
===By chemical contamination=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Year !!Event !!Food!! Contaminant!! Location !! Affected!! Deaths !! Notes |- | 1971 || [[1971 Iraq poison grain disaster]] ||wheat, barley|| [[methylmercury]] ||[[Iraq]] || {{sort|000650|>650}} ||{{sort|00650|650}} ||Seeds treated with methylmercury as a fungicide for planting were used as food |- |1981 || [[1981 Spain rapeseed oil toxicity]] || [[rapeseed oil]] || possibly [[aniline]]|| Spain || {{sort|025000|~25,000}} ||{{sort|00600|600}}||Industrial oil sold as food oil.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=A Long Trial in Spain on Fatal Tainted Food |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/02/world/a-long-trial-in-spain-on-fatal-tainted-food.html |quote= According to official figures, still disputed, more than 600 people have died and some 25,000 have been affected. ... |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=August 2, 1987 |accessdate=2011-10-10 }}</ref> |- |1955 || {{ill|Morinaga milk arsenic poisoning|ja|森永ヒ素ミルク中毒事件}}<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dakeishi|first=Miwako|last2=Murata|first2=Katsuyuki|last3=Grandjean|first3=Philippe|date=2006|title=Long-term consequences of arsenic poisoning during infancy due to contaminated milk powder|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1186/1476-069X-5-31|journal=Environmental Health|volume=5|pages=31|doi=10.1186/1476-069X-5-31|issn=1476-069X|pmc=1635412|pmid=17076881}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archive.unu.edu/unupress/unupbooks/uu35ie/uu35ie09.htm|title=Chapter - 3 The arsenic milk poisoning incident|website=archive.unu.edu|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref> ||[[Powdered milk]] || [[arsenic]] || [[Japan]] ||{{sort|013389|13,389}} ||{{sort|00600|>600}} ||By mistake, an industrial grade [[Monosodium phosphate]] was added to milk produced by [[Morinaga Milk Industry]], which contained an impurity of 5–8% arsenic. The milk powder was used for feeding infants, and many babies were poisoned. By 1981, there were still >6,000 people affected as adults with severe mental retardation and other health effects; and by 2006, >600 adults remained affected. |- | 1900 || [[1900 English beer poisoning]] || [[beer]] || [[arsenic]] || England || {{sort|006000|>6,000}} || {{sort|00070|>70}} || Arsenic was introduced into beer via contaminated sugar. Outbreak made worse by mass-misdiagnosis of the victims' illnesses. |- |1858 || [[1858 Bradford sweets poisoning]] ||[[candy]] || arsenic trioxide || England ||{{sort|000200|~200}} ||{{sort|00020|20}} ||Arsenic was accidentally sold as "daft". Daft was a standard adulterant to bulk up the candy |- | 2008 || [[2008 Chinese milk scandal]] || [[milk]] ||[[melamine]] and [[urea]] ||China||{{sort|300000|>300,000}} ||{{sort|00006|6}}||Milk diluted with water then melamine added to fool the test for protein content |}
